data.title: 22nd Infantry War of 1812 Dead
data.text:
1st Battalion 22nd Infantry

22nd Infantry Dead and Missing of the War of 1812

June 1812 - February 1815

A Private of Brigadier General Winfield Scott's 1st Brigade of

Major General Jacob Brown's Left Division of the U.S. Army

1812-1815

This uniform with the grey jacket was worn by the Soldiers of the 22nd Infantry

as part of General Scott's Brigade on the battlefields at Chippewa and Lundy's Lane.

As painted by Don Troiani from the book: Don Troiani's Soldiers in America, 1754-1865

Publisher Stackpole Books, 1998

The following list was compiled using six main sources. Where conflicts existed for an entry

the Register of Enlistments was used as the final authority for enlisted men and the

Official Army Register as the final authority for officers.

More than two-thirds of the names listed below were found only in the enlistment records

and not in any other sources. Enlistment records were found for all except thirteen of the names.

Not every enlistment record contained a complete set of details for every name.

Where available in the record such details are given here. Not every

date or cause of death could be found but is given where known.

Unless indicated as missing all names are to be considered as died.

There was no uniformity in the original accounts of recording the cause of death.

The term "Killed" always indicated killed in action but the term "Died" (without giving

a cause of death) could also indicate killed in action or dying of wounds received in action.

Often the original accounts used the phrase "Dead or missing date unknown" or "Dead or

missing date not known" and those phrases are repeated here.

Names are listed by last name, first name, middle initial if known, then date of death if known.

Note: The Battle of Lundy's Lane, Canada was fought on July 25, 1814. Contemporary American accounts called the location

Bridgewater, Upper Canada and in the Register of Enlistments nearly all references to the battle denote it as Bridgewater,

not Lundy's Lane. The battle was also sometimes called the Battle of Niagara or the Battle of Niagara Falls. Canadian accounts

and later American accounts use the name Lundy's Lane thus that name is used in these listings to denote the battle in order to

avoid any confusion regarding the location.

Sources:

Register of Enlistments in the U.S. Army, 1798-1914;

National Archives Microfilm Publication M233

(Referred to below as Register)

Official Army Registers for 1812, 1813, 1814, 1815

Government Printing Office Washington, D.C.

(Referred to below as Official Army Register)

KNOWN MILITARY DEAD DURING WAR OF 1812

Compiled by Ex-Lieut. Clarence Stewart Peterson, M.A.

Self published Baltimore, Maryland April 1955

(Referred to below as Peterson)

THE TWENTY-SECOND UNITED STATES INFANTRY A Forgotten Regiment in a Forgotten War 1812-1815

by John Newell Crombie

Western Pennsylvania Historical Quarterly Volume 50, Number 2 April 1967 pp. 133-148

(Referred to below as Crombie)

THE TWENTY-SECOND UNITED STATES INFANTRY A Forgotten Regiment in a Forgotten War 1812-1815 Part II

by John Newell Crombie

Western Pennsylvania Historical Quarterly Volume 50, Number 3 July 1967 pp. 221-238

(Referred to below as Crombie)

RED COATS & GREY JACKETS The Battle of Chippawa 5 July 1814

by Donald E. Graves

Dundurn Press Niagara Falls, N.Y. 1994

(Referred to below as Graves)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Michael Belis December 2017

ALEXANDER SAMUEL.....11/02/1814 - Private - Died at Genessee, New York - Company commanded by CPT Willis Foulk - Enlisted July 23, 1812 - Register indicated he stood 5 feet 9 inches tall, had brown eyes, brown hair, fair complexion, previous occupation of Nailer, age at enlistment was 42, born in Derry, Ireland. Register indicates Alexander supposed murdered by James Hamelton while on march from Williamsville to Sackett's Harbor. (That soldier's name was actually John Hamilton of the same Company as Alexander. Private John Hamilton was remanded to civil authorities for Alexander's murder. A final disposition for Hamilton could not be found. If indeed he were hanged for Alexander's murder then Hamilton should also be included in these listings as one of the 22nd Infantry's dead from all causes during the war.)
